results.title: Rue Cases-Negres = Black Shack Alley = Sugar Cane Alley
results.creator_credit: Alex Regis, Michel Loulergue and Euzhan Palcy
results.brief_description:
Martinique-born Palcy, in her first feature, portrays some of the realities of colonialism. Although set in the 1930s the position of the dispossessed is little changed despite the evolution of the political situation as the economy remains in the hands of Martinique-born whites. The story, based on the novel by a black writer from the island, centers on a young boy from a cane-cutter’s village and his grandmother who works hard to provide him with an education as the means of breaking out of the cycle of poverty. The third main character is an old man who tells the boy the history of his people. Awards: Venice Film Festival (1983) Best Actress for Darling Legitmus ; French Academy of Cinema (Cesar) 1983: Best First Film for director Euzhan Palcy.

Credits: Producer, Michel Loulergue, Alex Regis ; director, writer, Euzhan Palcy ; photography, Dominique Chapuis ; music, Malavoi.
Cast: Garry Cadenat, Darling Legitmus, Douta Seck.

results.title: Rudyard Kipling's How the elephant got his trunk (K)
results.creator_credit: Encyclopaedia Britannica Films and Ed Newmann
results.brief_description: Based on Rudyard Kipling’s classic fable in the “Just So Stories” series, this beautifully presented story in claymation tells of a young elephant who learns the price and reaps the rewards of curiosity. When the elephant asks the crocodile what he has for dinner, the crocodile clamps the elephant’s stubby nose in his teeth. Pulling away, the elephant finds his nose is stretched completely out of shape - but to his surprise he discovers the long trunk is useful in a number of ways.
results.title_for_label: Rudyard Kipling’s How the elephant got his trunk (K)

results.title: Rudyard Kipling's How the elephant got his trunk
results.creator_credit: Nick Bosustow, Stephen Bosustow Productions and Lee Mishkin
results.brief_description: An animated film based on a story from the “Just So Stories” by Rudyard Kipling. A curious elephant calf sets out to find what the crocodile has for dinner. The crocodile attacks and in his effort to escape the elephant finds his nose somewhat elongated.

results.title: Rude Journee Pour la Reine = Rough Day for the Queen
results.brief_description:
A day in the life of an ordinary family: Jeanne works as a cleaning lady, Albert is a night watchman. Julien, their son is arrested. At his release, his attempts to establish contact with his girlfriend Annie are thwarted by her parents who oppose the relationship. Departing from her usual role of victim and servant, Jeanne decides to plot to reunite the two lovers. To achieve this, she resorts to a secret weapon: her vivid imagination and her Walter Mitty-like fantasies of being a queen.

Credits: Producer, Yves Gasser ; director, Rene Allio ; writers, Gerard Chartreux, Janine Peyre ; photography, Denys Clerval ; music, Philippe Arthuys.
Cast: Simone Signoret, Jacques Debary, Olivier Perrier, Orane Demazis, Christiane Rorato, Gerard Depardieu.

results.title: Rude awakening
results.creator_credit: Aaron Russo, Orion Pictures Corporation and David Greenwalt
results.brief_description: Rude awakening is just that, when hippies Hesus and Fred return to New York after spending twenty years at a hippie commune in Central America, they find that things have not stayed the same and are in for one awakening they did not expect. They return to New York armed with Government papers that fell into their hands informing them of a proposed war in Central America. Needing the help and support of their old friends, they soon find they have changed from the once youthful free spirited drug taking hippies, to the uptight hard nosed yuppies that they used to despise. “Rude awakening” looks at the environmental challenges our world faces and the reluctance by people to stand up and express their anger and objection to the destruction of a highly delicate world in which we live. Cast includes Eric Roberts, Cheech Marin, Robert Carradine and Julie Hagerty.

results.title: Rude
results.creator_credit: Feature Film Project, Conquering Lion Production, Karen King, Damon D'Oliveira, Colin Brunton and Clement Virgo
results.brief_description: This urban drama, the first feature length Canadian film to be made by an all black crew, is set amid a group of disenchanted black teenagers living in the ‘projects’ (public housing) who seek to express themselves, as they struggle against the confines of their lower class economic constraints that exclude them from mainstream society. Rude is an underground female pirate DJ who, seeking a voice for the troubles that seethe around her, transmits to the projects; General arrives home from jail spell for drug dealing to reconcile with his wife, Jessica (a police officer) and son; General’s brother longs for Jessica, and works for a white racist drug lord; Jordan, a young boxer, participates in gay bashing, despite his burgeoning desire for men; disconsolate Maxine reflects upon a failed relationship. The fortunes of these characters represent the disempowerment of Canadian minority groups, whose failure to have their cultural origins acknowledged within the broader milieu of the community is echoed in numerous misguided and frustrated acts of aggression. The explicit, rhythmic, political, and erotic rapping of Rude mirrors a potent narrative, moving and frightening in its intensity as it explores the themes of social isolation, homophobia, abortion, drug abuse and the violent expressions of youth.

results.title: Ruby and Rata
results.creator_credit: Preston-Laing Productions, New Zealand Film Commission, Robin Laing and Gaylene Preston
results.brief_description: Comedy drama about the relationship between two New Zealand women who seemingly have absolutely nothing in common, apart from their fierce independence. Rata, is a single Maori mother in her twenties frauding the welfare system in order to get by. Ruby, is an elderly Pakeha, an intolerant, middle-class pensioner, who owns her own home in the Auckland suburbs. The two are thrown together when Ruby’s nephew rents her basement flat to Rata. When Ruby discovers that Rata is not the nice young single professional woman she imagined, but has a wild young son named Willie who sings in a rowdy band, she tries unsuccessfully to evict her. Yet their mutual hostility gradually wanes, largely due to the intervention of Willie, who strikes up an odd relationship with Ruby. Eventually the two women find common ground and pool their resources to survive. The film critiques the economic rationalism that took hold in New Zealand in the eighties, while celebrating the perseverance of ordinary people caught in an economic and social underclass. Cast includes Yvonne Lawley, Vanessa Rare, Simon Barnett and Lee Mete-Kingi.

results.title: Rubens [B&W]
results.creator_credit: Ministere de l'Instruction Publique et le Ministere des Communications Belgique, Paul Haesaerts and Henri Storck
results.brief_description: This film received 1st prize at the 1948 International Film Festival at Venice. It opens with an analysis of Rubens’ style. Comparisons are made with other painters by using a split screen. After this contrasting of styles and compositions, the film introduces actuality shots of clouds, water and flames, superimposed over paintings showing clearly the corresponding fluidity and roundness of Rubens’ general style. The second section of the film deals with Rubens’ life, his family, his travels and his methods of working. Photography by Robert Gudin. Translation and narration by Charles Jarrell.

results.title: Rubens
results.creator_credit: International Film Bureau Inc, Resobel and John Cleinge
results.brief_description: Presents the life and work of Rubens. Through biographical information and a look at a range of his paintings Ruben’s message of personal and artistic freedom is emphasised.

results.title: Rubella
results.creator_credit: Rubella Committee Deafness Foundation of Victoria
results.brief_description: Designed to inform pubescent and teenaged girls of the need to vaccinate against German measles to prevent rubella in the unborn child. Outlines the congenital defects caused by rubella in the first six weeks of pregnancy. Suitable for lower and middle secondary levels.
